dt: {bc}to fasten, join, or secure with a pin

dt.t: She {wi}pinned{/wi} the corsage to her dress.
… all the big brass is standing at attention and the biggest brass of all is waiting to {wi}pin{/wi} a medal on my chest …
The three men held him {wi}pinned{/wi} against the wall …
Rescue crews freed the people who were {wi}pinned{/wi} under the wreckage.
They were {wi}pinned{/wi} down by enemy fire.

dt: {bc}to present (a young woman) with a fraternity pin as a pledge of affection

dt.t: Pinterest is {wi}pinning{/wi} its future on Wall Street, with the digital scrapbooking site … filing for an initial public offering of stock.

dt: {bc}to assign the blame or responsibility for

dt.t: They tried to {wi}pin{/wi} the robbery on a night watchman

dt: {bc}to define or determine clearly or precisely

dt.t: it is hard to {wi}pin{/wi} down exactly when things changed

dt: {bc}to fix (something, such as a message, a file, or an icon) in place for convenient viewing or access

dt.t: This is one of the most useful features of the new Twitter—you can {wi}pin{/wi} a tweet on your profile so that it stays on top …
{ldquo}Need to {wi}pin{/wi} a file or a message to the channel so people can access it quickly and easily? No problem!{rdquo} Slack said in a blog post on the new feature today.

Many companies scrambled to get their heads around how to use their existing technology infrastructure to work remotely. For them, Microsoft Teams was just an icon {wi}pinned{/wi} to their menu bar that lay dormant.

dt: {bc}to make (a chess opponent's piece) unable to move without exposing the king to check or a valuable piece to capture

dt.t: The white queen {wi}pins{/wi} the black bishop.
In five years of wrestling at Exeter, I probably {wi}pinned{/wi} no more than a half-dozen opponents. I was almost never {wi}pinned{/wi}—only twice, in fact.

shortdef: to fasten, join, or secure with a pin
to present (a young woman) with a fraternity pin as a pledge of affection

dt: {bc}to cause or force (someone) to make a definite statement or decision about something

dt.t: Reporters tried to {wi}pin{/wi} him {wi}down{/wi} on the specific changes he wants to make to the tax laws.
Can you {wi}pin down{/wi} when the change occurred?
I'm trying to {wi}pin{/wi} the source of the problem {wi}down{/wi}.

shortdef: to cause or force (someone) to make a definite statement or decision about something

dt: {bc}to hope very much for a good outcome from (something or someone) especially when other options are not available or are not pursued

dt.t: Also, if possible, generate several [job] interviews; don't {wi}pin your hopes on{/wi} just one.
Calgary is holding its breath, {wi}pinning its hopes on{/wi} a goalie who's all too human.
I wanted this intense stranger who found me to be different—to be, against all odds, the one. So I {wi}pinned all my hopes on{/wi} him.

shortdef: to hope very much for a good outcome from (something or someone) especially when other options are not available or are not pursued

dt.t: When he got caught, he tried to {wi}pin the blame on{/wi} someone else.
Eventually, researchers and governments did definitively {wi}pin the blame{/wi} for that incident {wi}on{/wi} the Russian government …

shortdef: to assign (someone) the blame for something
